text: relief efforts in Haiti are clearly
picking up 48 hours after a massive
earthquake destroyed the capital city of
port-au-prince with us now is Mark lacy
The Times Caribbean bureau chief who has
arrived in port-au-prince Jane I just
flew in to port-au-prince and the scene
from overhead is pretty dramatic you can
see destroyed roofs on small building
small shanties on big buildings what
looked like what looked like hospitals
supermarkets that sort of thing it's
dramatic this this earthquake there's no
doubt about it caused significant damage
all over port-au-prince clearly the
relief efforts I have stepped up but our
relief agency is able to get any of this
aid into the city itself Jane the relief
is really just beginning to arrive here
at the airport the cargo planes are
being unloaded and it's starting to
reach port-au-prince the situation in
the capital is desperate people need
food and medicine water but it's not
coming in fast enough for relief workers
say and there's a lot more that's needed
and a lot more that's on the way what
about is there any sign of civil unrest
there we were hearing that a residents
of port-au-prince were actually coming
to the airport to try and get aid have
you seen any evidence of that or any
evidence of you know disturbances in the
streets there there's a lot of tension
outside the airport there's a lot of
people gathered there that's the great
fear that as this tragedy as as the
strategy extends into days and people
aren't getting food aren't getting water
as their as their suffering that they're
going to get angrier and that unrest is
a possibility so that's the great fear I
haven't seen evidence of it yet mark I
saw behind you a little bit ago a
forklift that seemed like a good start I
mean is there any heavy equipment being
brought in to clear the roads clear the
debris so this aid can get through there
is equipment coming in search and rescue
teams have arrived from Los Angeles from
Virginia from Miami they're going to go
through the rubble with you know by hand
they brought in specially trained dogs
they brought in equipment so they're
leaving the airport and heading out to
some of these awful scenes out there in
the capital where there's piles of
rubble and there's believed to be people
still alive inside so they're heading
out there now and so that's just
beginning mark does anybody seem to be
completely in control this situation is
that the United Nations is the US
government and for you know involved
who's really coordinating all this I am
not seeing a great deal of presents I'm
not seeing any presence of the Haitian
government here at the airport
I see soldiers from all over the world
most of them from the United States
I see relief agencies but it's very
unclear who's running the show and and
it certainly is not the Haitian
government mark I know you came in with
doctors and I'm curious I'm how many how
much honey supplies are they able to
bring are they getting them to the
hospitals or shut down right or not
functioning so where are they going
where they setting up headquarters or
how are they operating exactly I came in
with a small group of doctors from Miami
and these these are doctors who
regularly come to Haiti to do surgeries
and and other work here
they came mainly on an assessment
mission but they said they're going to
roll up their sleeves and get started on
first aid as well they brought some
drugs some basic equipment and they're
going to get started medical supplies
are an extremely short supply here in in
in port-au-prince right now all sorts of
drugs are needed really everything's
needed this is a place that's going to
run out of food unless more food is
brought in water everything is needed
this is a country that needs the world
to pour in relief when I go back to the
United States government's involvement
what's your sense of the presence of the
United States there is there a sense
that the US is reacting quickly enough
well it there there's a there's a large
presence of American military the USAID
here at the airport there
no doubt about it there's there's
American non-governmental agencies that
are arriving there there's a great large
American presence at the airport
it's unclear to me how much aid is
actually getting out to people how
quickly that's happening and that's
really all that matters and that's the
big question are Haitians who suffered a
devastating earthquake a few days ago
are they getting relief and and they
need relief there's no doubt about it
